raw_text:
BP surges ahead on high oil price
 
 Oil giant BP has announced a 26% rise in annual profits to $16.2bn (£8.7bn) on the back of record oil prices.
 
 Last week, rival Shell reported an annual profit of $17.5bn - a record profit for a UK-listed company. BP added that it was increasing its fourth-quarter dividend by 26% to 8.5 cents, and that it would continue with share buybacks. BP chief executive Lord Browne said the results were strong "both operationally and financially."
 
 The company is earning about $1.8m an hour.
 
 Despite the record annual profits figure, BP's performance was below the expectations of some City analysts. However, BP's share price rose 4p or nearly 1% in morning trading to 548p. Its profit rise for the year included profits of $3.65bn (£1.97bn) for the final three months of 2004 - up from $2.89bn a year ago but below its third quarter.
 
 Speaking on the BBC's Today programme on Tuesday, Lord Browne said the profits were not solely down to the high oil price alone.
 
 "The profits are up more than the price of oil is up," he said. Lord Browne pointed out that BP was reaping the benefits of its investment in oil exploration. "We have spent many years buying (assets) when the price is low," he said. The company has made new discoveries in Egypt, the Gulf of Mexico and Angola.
 
 However, Lord Browne rejected calls for a windfall tax on his company's huge profits, saying that in the North Sea it paid progressively more tax, the more profits it made. Lord Browne believes oil prices will remain quite high. Currently above $40 a barrel, he said: "The price of oil will be well supported above $30 a barrel for the medium term." BP put production for the year at 3.997 billion barrels of oil, up 10% on 2003, but slightly lower than the four billion barrels it had initially aimed for.
llama3.2:1b: BP reported a 26% increase in annual profits to $16.2bn (£8.7bn) due to record high oil prices, with profits rising to $3.65bn (£1.97bn) in the final three months of 2004. Despite this, some analysts were below expectations due to the company's lower-than-expected third quarter profit. BP's share price rose 4p or nearly 1% in morning trading.
llama3.2:3b: BP's annual profits rose to $16.2bn with a 26% increase, driven by record high oil prices, and announced a 26% increase in quarterly dividends. Despite some analysts' disappointment, BP's share price rose 4p or nearly 1%. Lord Browne attributed the profit rise to investments in oil exploration and said oil prices will remain above $30 a barrel for the medium term.
gemma2:2b:
BP's annual profits surged to $16.2bn due to record oil prices. The company attributed its strong performance to investment in exploration and high oil prices exceeding price increases. Despite some analyst expectations not being met, share prices rose 4p on the news. 
  
 BP plans to increase its dividend and continue with buybacks while CEO Lord Browne believes oil prices will remain above $30 a barrel for the foreseeable future.
qwen2.5:0.5b: BP reported record profits and increased its dividend by 26%. Although the figures are high, they were well below the analysts' expectations in terms of share price performance. However, BP's profits rose more than oil prices rose, which shows the potential for a strong future growth. The company's investment in exploration has paid off and it is expected that oil prices will remain quite high.
qwen2.5:1.5b: BP's annual profits jumped by 26%, reaching $16.2bn after record high oil prices, despite some analysts expecting higher-than-expected dividends and share buybacks, increasing earnings to about $1.8m per hour, which rose 4p or nearly 1% in morning trading to 548p on strong performance driven by increased profits of $3.65bn for the final quarter of 2004, despite BP's profit falling slightly short of expectations due to its investments and high oil prices forecast to remain stable above $30 per barrel until at least mid-term.
qwen2.5:3b: BP reported a 26% increase in annual profits to $16.2bn (£8.7bn) driven by record high oil prices. Despite this, BP's performance was under analyst expectations. The company increased its fourth-quarter dividend and announced share buybacks. BP's profit rise for the year included a final three-month profit of $3.65bn (£1.97bn), up from $2.89bn a year ago but below expected third quarter levels. Lord Browne attributed this to investments in oil exploration, including recent discoveries in Egypt, the Gulf of Mexico, and Angola. He also noted BP's ability to pay progressively more tax as profits increase, while rejecting calls for a windfall tax on its profits. Browne predicted that oil prices will remain high above $30 per barrel for the medium term, currently at over $40 per barrel.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and to the point, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information. The main points are:

1. BP has announced a 26% rise in annual profits on record oil prices.
2. Last week, Shell reported an annual profit of $17.5bn - a record profit for a UK-listed company.
3. BP added that it was increasing its fourth-quarter dividend by 26% to 8.5 cents.
4. The company is earning about $1.8m an hour.
5. Despite the record annual profits figure, BP's performance was below expectations of some City analysts.
6. However, BP's profit rise for the year included profits of $3.65bn (£1.97bn) for the final three months of 2004 - up from $2.89bn a year ago but below its third quarter.
7. Speaking on the BBC's Today programme on Tuesday, Lord Browne said the profits were not solely down to the high oil price alone.
8. The profits are up more than the price of oil is up.
9. Lord Browne rejected calls for a windfall tax on his company's huge profits, saying that in the North Sea it paid progressively more tax, the more profits it made.
10. BP put production for the year at 3.997 billion barrels of oil - up 10% on 2003.

The summary captures the main points from the original text while omitting unnecessary information and focusing on key ideas and details.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about BP and their profits in a concise way. Let me read through the provided text first.

The text starts by saying BP has surged ahead on high oil prices, rising 26% to $16.2 billion in profits. It mentions Shell beat its record with $17.5 billion. Then, BP's CEO says their performance was mixed because some analysts thought their profits didn't meet expectations. However, their share price went up a bit.

BP is making about $1.8 million per hour. Despite high profits, some analysts expected them to do better. But the profits included profits from 2004's last quarter and more in March. They were higher than two years ago but lower this year. Lord Browne said profits are partly due to oil exploration costs. He pointed out they've been investing in oil when prices were low, like in Egypt, Gulf of Mexico, and Angola.

He rejected a tax on their huge profits, saying the North Sea taxed more as oil prices went up. He expects oil prices to stay above $30 a barrel for now and possibly higher in the future. BP's production was up 10% from 2003 but still below their goal of 4 billion barrels.

So the key points are: BP has strong profits, high oil prices pushed them up, Shell beat its record with more profit. Share price went up slightly, expected profits were mixed by analysts. Some factors contributing to higher profits, mainly investment in exploration and higher taxes in the North Sea.
</think>

BP surged ahead due to rising oil prices, rising 26% to $16.2 billion annually. Shell surpassed its record with $17.5 billion profit. BP CEO Lord Browne highlighted strong performance both operationally and financially. 

BP makes ~$1.8 million per hour. Profit expectations were mixed by analysts but share price up 4p, now at 548p. Profit increases included $3.65 billion from last three months (up from $2.89 billion) and lower in March. High oil prices pushed some tax expectations aside. 

Lord Browne emphasized profits partly due to exploration investment. He noted progressively higher taxes in the North Sea as profits increased. He expects oil prices above $40/barrel for now, targeting possibly higher rates. BP's production up 10% from 2003 but still below their target of 4 billion barrels.
tinyllama:1.1b: BP, a major international oil company, has reported an increase in annual profit by 26% to $16.2bn (£8.7bn), surpassing rival Shell's record profits of $17.5bn a year earlier. The company declared that it was increasing its fourth-quarter dividend to 8.5c, and announced plans for further share buybacks in the coming months. Despite the high oil prices, BP's performance was below analyst expectations, with some investors suggesting a windfall tax on its massive profits. However, CEO Lord Brown said that the company had invested heavily in new discoveries and made progressively more progressive taxes, and reiterated his belief that oil prices would remain high over the medium term. Despite reports of lower production levels, BP's fourth-quarter results were considered solid by market analysts, with shares rising 4p or nearly 1% in morning trading to 548p.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summary: BP, an oil company, reported a 26% rise in profits and increased its fourth-quarter dividend by 26%. The results were strong both operationally and financially. Despite being below expectations of some analysts, the company's performance was better than expected due to high oil prices and investments in new assets.
phi:2.7b: Oil giant BP has reported a 26% increase in annual profits to $16.2bn (£8.7bn) due to record oil prices. Despite not meeting the expectations of some analysts, the company's share price rose by 4p or nearly 1%. However, Lord Browne cautioned that the profits were not solely based on the high oil price and highlighted BP's investment in oil exploration as a contributing factor. The company made new discoveries in Egypt, the Gulf of Mexico, and Angola. While calls for a windfall tax have been raised, Lord Browne rejects this idea and suggests that North Sea taxes are higher with increasing profits. He predicts that oil prices will remain high, currently above $40 per barrel. Production for the year was 3.997 billion barrels of oil, up 10% from 2003, although slightly lower than BP's initial target of four billion barrels.
orca-mini:3b: BP has reported a 26% rise in annual profits to $16.2bn due to record high oil prices, despite concerns among some analysts that its performance was below expectations. The company's share price rose by 4p or nearly 1% in morning trading to 548p, while Lord Browne said the profits were not solely down to the high oil price alone, but also due to its investment in oil exploration. BP paid progressively more tax on its North Sea profits, and believes oil prices will remain quite high.
hermes3:3b: BP reports 26% increase in annual profits to $16.2bn due to high oil prices, though below analyst expectations.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Oil giant BP announced a 26% increase in annual profits to $16.2bn (£8.7bn) due to record oil prices. The company increased its fourth-quarter dividend by 26% and plans continued share buybacks. BP CEO Lord Browne said the results were strong operationally and financially, with profits not solely based on high oil prices. He also mentioned new discoveries in Egypt, Gulf of Mexico, and Angola. However, Lord Browne rejected calls for a windfall tax on BP's profits, stating that the company pays more tax as profits increase.
chatgpt-4o-latest: BP reported a 26% rise in annual profits to $16.2bn, driven by record oil prices. Rival Shell posted a record $17.5bn profit. BP increased its fourth-quarter dividend by 26% and continued share buybacks. Despite strong financial results, BP's performance fell short of some analysts' expectations, though its share price rose nearly 1%. CEO Lord Browne attributed the gains not just to high oil prices but also to strategic investments in oil exploration, with new discoveries in Egypt, the Gulf of Mexico, and Angola. He dismissed calls for a windfall tax, citing BP's progressive tax payments in the North Sea. Browne predicted oil prices would stay above $30 a barrel in the medium term. BP's production rose 10% to 3.997 billion barrels, slightly below its four-billion-barrel target.
stablelm2:1.6b: BP reports a 16% rise in annual profits to £8.7bn ($2.2bn) due to high oil prices; Shell's profit was a record £5bn ($1.5bn). Despite the increase, BP's performance fell short of analyst expectations. The company earned about $1.8m an hour and will increase dividends by 3%. Lord Browne argues that profits are not solely linked to oil price changes and cite investments in oil exploration as a significant contributor. Oil prices are predicted to remain high, but the exact level is uncertain. BP aims for 3 billion barrels of production this year.
granite3.1-dense:2b: BP reported a 26% annual profit surge to $16.2bn (£8.7bn), driven by record oil prices and strategic investments in exploration, resulting in increased dividends and share buybacks. Despite falling short of analyst expectations, BP's share price rose slightly. The company attributed its profits to long-term value creation rather than just high oil prices, citing significant discoveries in Egypt, the Gulf of Mexico, and Angola. CEO Lord Browne anticipates sustained oil prices above $30 a barrel for the medium term, dismissing calls for a windfall tax due to progressive North Sea tax rates that increase with profits. BP's annual production was 3.997 billion barrels, an 10% increase from 2003 but below the initially targeted four billion barrels.
reference: "The profits are up more than the price of oil is up," he said.Speaking on the BBC's Today programme on Tuesday, Lord Browne said the profits were not solely down to the high oil price alone.Oil giant BP has announced a 26% rise in annual profits to $16.2bn (£8.7bn) on the back of record oil prices.Lord Browne believes oil prices will remain quite high.Last week, rival Shell reported an annual profit of $17.5bn - a record profit for a UK-listed company.Lord Browne pointed out that BP was reaping the benefits of its investment in oil exploration.Currently above $40 a barrel, he said: "The price of oil will be well supported above $30 a barrel for the medium term."
